column1: '''Eryn Vorn''' ([[Sindarin]] for '''Blackwood'''<ref name=RClxv/>) was a wooded cape in [[Eriador]]<ref name=UT>{{UT
column2: 6d}}</ref>, and a region of dark pine trees.<ref>{{webcite
column5: articlename=Tolkien’s annotated map of Middle-earth transcribed

column1: Located in western [[Minhiriath]], Eryn Vorn (likely named so by the Númenóreans) was originally part of the vast ancient treescape that covered most of north-western [[Middle-earth]]. During the Second Age, however, these forests were decimated by the [[Númenóreans]] in their greed for ship-building timber, before being almost completely burnt down by the forces of [[Sauron]] during the ensuing war in Eriador.<ref name=UT/>

By the latter half of the Second Age, the surviving natives of Minhiriath had retreated either north to [[Bree]], or hidden themselves in Eryn Vorn which was probably all that remained of the vast forests in Minhiriath for long years thereafter.

column2: 861}}, Eryn Vorn nominally formed a part of [[Cardolan]] and by the end of the Third Age, scattered woodlands had reappeared in much of the rest of Minhiriath.

column1: It is probable that people remained hidden in Eryn Vorn by the [[Third Age]]. Although Bree was the westernmost permanent settlement of [[Men]] by the late Third Age,<ref>{{HM
column2: RK}}</ref>{{fact}} the woods of Minhiriath were home of a few, secretive hunter-folk at the time of the [[War of the Ring]]. These wild people were afraid to cross the river [[Baranduin]] because of the Elves who dwelt beyond.<ref name=UT/><ref group="note">These Elves surely are the Elves of [[Lindon]], the realm located north of the cape.<!-- noted by User:Morgan --></ref>

column1: ''Eryn Vorn'' is [[Sindarin]] and has been given the translation "Blackwood". The name consists of ''[[eryn]]'' ("wood") and ''vorn'' ("dark"),<ref name=RClxv>{{HM
column2: RC}}, p. lxv</ref> the latter being the [[lenition
column3: lenited]] form of ''[[morn]]''.<ref>[[Helge Fauskanger]], "[http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/sindarin.htm Sindarin - the Noble Tongue: I. Soft Mutation]" at [http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/ Ardalambion] (accessed 8 June 2011)</ref>

column1: The name ''Eryn Vorn'' first appeared on [[Pauline Baynes]]'s ''[[A Map of Middle-earth]]'' ([[1970]]), for which [[J.R.R. Tolkien
column2: Tolkien]] had supplied [https://www.tolkiensociety.org/2015/11/tolkiens-annotated-map-of-middle-earth-transcribed/ notes] on additional names. The first printing of the map wrongly has ''Erin Voru''.<ref name=RClxv/>

column1: : Eryn Vorn, the Black Wood (called ''Choil Borba'' in the local tongue), covers the promontory of Rast Vorn (the Dark Cape). The large wood is a wild land, inhabited by [[Woses]] and evil creatures.<ref>{{ICE
